column1: Reviews

Duolingo was a great learning app but parts I hate. I learn 3 languages. French, mandarin, and Spanish. Sadly, sometimes, updates like adventure or the radio is something I want to try! I have legendary for literally the entire section two in french, so I COULDN'T DO IT. Sometimes updates changes your learning level but when I head into Chinese, I don't know a thing. When it changed I had no idea what was anything so I had to retry my entire progress. Please improve this. Would'be given 5 stars.

I checked the alphabet tab and suddenly I found out that it has words for each of kanji letter (I am learning Japanese and Mandarin) and their meanings too. Maybe finally this app has added words that I've learned from the lessons. This is really important for me to review the words I learned. Also, there's too much vibration on each animation though.

I would've gave this learning app 5 stars review if it not making me keep repeating courses that I've done before everytime there was a big update. As a learning app, this app is wonderful, the courses are gradually level up in the nice pace. But everytime there is a big update of the courses, my completed "legendary" level of the courses are gone, I've to re-do almost everything again, and it happened 3times already, it's frustrating. And if it happen again, then I would've quit this app.

Duolingo was a great learning app but parts I hate. I learn 3 languages. French, mandarin, and Spanish. Sadly, sometimes, updates like adventure or the radio is something I want to try! I have legendary for literally the entire section two in french, so I COULDN'T DO IT. Sometimes updates changes your learning level but when I head into Chinese, I don't know a thing. When it changed I had no idea what was anything so I had to retry my entire progress. Please improve this. Would'be given 5 stars.

I checked the alphabet tab and suddenly I found out that it has words for each of kanji letter (I am learning Japanese and Mandarin) and their meanings too. Maybe finally this app has added words that I've learned from the lessons. This is really important for me to review the words I learned. Also, there's too much vibration on each animation though.

I would've gave this learning app 5 stars review if it not making me keep repeating courses that I've done before everytime there was a big update. As a learning app, this app is wonderful, the courses are gradually level up in the nice pace. But everytime there is a big update of the courses, my completed "legendary" level of the courses are gone, I've to re-do almost everything again, and it happened 3times already, it's frustrating. And if it happen again, then I would've quit this app.

Been using this app for more than 30 days, i was really enjoy it, this app helps me to improve my chinese. However since they changed the sequence of hanzi, it has become harder to learn and practice lessons. The words are no longer linked, makes it difficult to focus on learning new words and sentences at one time. Hopefully the team listen and aware about this impact and restore the structure to prev version :)

Great UI, but very slow paced learning. This is a bad alternative to learning any languages, compared with 1. Books 2. Video lessons 3. Live courses 4. Flashcards The selection of words from their "keyboard" honestly makes it look more like a jigsaw puzzle than what could've been a great source to train spelling abilities (such as Japanese, Chinese, and Korean characters). I do understand that a lot of sentences can be expressed in many different ways, though, so this isn't quite a major issue.

the practice is good, you can skip part of it if you think you're good enough.. i cant complain much about anything really.. however, if you learnt lot of vocab in japanese, use other app. This app has a slow pace, in kanji departement, you can learn it but it was slow, what would be great is if it would have some test about all kanji that you have unlocked. If you hear me dev. Team please implement this thanks

So far so good, on a free plan but will consider a subscription Edit, just had a notification to upgrade, actually the price is OK, but there is no option to pay monthly, all in one go 12 months up front, the problem with that is somewhere like Indonesia that is a lot of money up front that very few can afford, making the payment monthly is much fairer and would I believe result in more people signing up.

With every update, it seems like Duolingo is upping the ante in trying to force a switch to paid version. When you go back to try to complete legendary status on an old lesson, the questions are very odd and obscure. Also, there are nearly all "fill in the blank boxes" without any supplied words or options. It's getting very challenging to even get to the half-way point without running out of hearts. I didn't have this problem before recent changes.

Easy to use and understand. The UI is great. I enjoy the variety of methods employed to get words and phrases over. My only quibble is that,despite turning off notificatiins,I keel getting notifications about the league or whatever it is,that I have ZERO interest in. I'm just trying to expand my brain. I don't want some childish competition thrown into the mix. Especially one that seems able to overrule my settings preferences!

Overall excellent user experience. The repetition is good to remember and learn efficiently, there is no better way to learn than by practicing the language, and Duolingo understood that. However, it spends way too much time on the same thing in my opinion, it is too stagnant and I would like to go faster through the subjects. It would be great if the course adapted to my learning abilities. Aside from that, at least for conjugation, it would be great to have sheets that go over everything.

Decent. I do Japanese and Spanish, and it's equally fine for both. Easy to practice listening and speaking, and for Japanese they have a place to practice just the writing. However, the app constantly changes your place in lessons, making it wildly difficult to know where you are and feel any sense of satisfaction with your progress. Competitiveness is now a non-negotiable component, and the app is now harder to navigate and it's significantly harder to find things. 3 stars.

Often laggy, and filled with bugs. Can't count experience points correctly or straight up doesn't, then tells me that my streak has been frozen but it ends up restarting it. And when I try to finish a level, sometimes it doesn't take the whole exercise in consideration because I closed the ads as soon as I could. This has been a day to day struggle for the past week and I know it sounds cheesy, but I have friends who experienced the same. But when it does cooperate I guess it's kind of fine. ‚úåüíÄ

Early user of the app. So far what it does is great! my only issue is I am not really into the "flare" aspect of it. An ability to turn off some of that while keeping the learning\test part would be well received. I don't care about streaks and gems and "way to go's". I tend to like subtle/simple/clean. There are many 'loading screens' and prompts. I am using the free version, so maybe some of that goes away if you pay ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. However I am not seeing any option screens to allow customization.

it's very engaging and emerrsive. it keeps you hooked. it's fun to keep at it and earn your spot on top of the leaderboards. take your time and don't make mistakes, and the free version is fine. if you find the courses getting challenging, getting super duo lingo paid for the unlimited hearts/ unlimited mistakes is worth it if you plan on sticking with it. i recommend waiting until you're offered the trail. if you don't use duo lingo much during your trail, don't upgrade.

it's a great learning app. You should take a look at their YouTube channel, they're very funny. Back to the topic. the app is amazing. I love that you can learn multiple languages easily. You can postpone the speaking and listening exercises for later, instead of having to leave and have all of your progress reset. anyway, have a nice day or night! Edit: I don't like the new app Icon. Can you change it back to the old one? The melted-looking face is scaring m

Great app for learning. I think the app does well to progress you, but it's also up to you to put in the work to actually learn, e.g. saying every sentence (or at least most of them) even if it doesn't require it, not hinting every word of you forget it, actually taking notes on hard phrases or at least screenshots and reviewing them later. Learning is hard and needs to be active, not passive, in order to truly comprehend the concept and phrases presented.

This app used to be great, but in recent months I have experienced numerous glitches. Daily challenges aren't recorded, points lag, and worst of all the practice sessions are almost always pronunciation or listening, which are difficult to do sometimes when in public. Clicking on "can't listen now" or "can't speak now" has no effect on the practice session. I have recorded these issues as feedback at least 3 times in the past few weeks, but nothing has changed.

It is very clever and very effective. Certainly keeps you motivated to keep using it and I got to speak Italian fast. Two downsides. Being AI driven it doesn't always make sense. Some translations it provides are literal and make no sense or it marks as a wrong answer if you put words not in the exact same order in the English language. The other very annoying downside is it is impossible to compete in the last two leaderboards against the paid accounts. I gave up on the leaderboards!

The learning lessons are great, and I am learning. The subscription is beneficial. However, it was not made clear that it would br charged in one yearly subscription, instead of the $10 a month it states (for family plan). This was a bit deceptive, especially since they did not give the 2 day warning it says it will give before charging your account.

A good way to learn the basics or to refresh memory of a language, especially vocabulary. while repetition is useful, sometimes it's too repetitive with limited opportunity to test out of easy stuff. I have just spent weeks learning more about 'lucha libre' (Mexican wrestling) than I ever wanted or would ever need. I am British and I am learning more about American English as well as learning (American) Spanish. Sometimes the English is really strange and I am not sure if it's a faulty translat

Thank you for this great app! I just wanted to tell you that, it would be great if you could expand the topics and words on the sections for Personalised practises. After some levels that you have in Practising sections, a lot of words and sentences are repeating and it is just making to learn only one particular part of the language. it would be great if you take a look on it ( I am talking about the section where app consists of only from Personalized practices). Have a good one!

The app itself is an amazing app such as to being a "free" learning app. But is it really so free because ever since they added all the "super Duolingo" stuff,it has been so annoying I'm getting ads all the time I'm restricted to features that should be available to the public. Another thing I'm mad about is ,the hearts. You should at least have maximum of 10 hearts. It gets so annoying whenever you lose all your hearts and have to get them back. So annoying but can be a really good app.

The path layout is still inferior to the old tree layout, and it seems duolingo is hellbent on sticking to the new format. Beyond that, the app frequently "updates" in a way that conveniently forces you to lose legendary status on levels you had previously completed. This, of course, means you have to redo them and that costs money (if you're not paying for Super Duolingo). It seems the focus has shifted from making a superior product to simply making more profits.

I have used Duolingo on and off for a decade. It does gamification very well, but it is so completely focused on translation, and the quality between courses varies greatly, especially if you aren't learning the most common languages. They push use on mobile devices, but the lessons, especially grammar are missing there. So very much potential, but they never fully realize it.

Quit fun, though sometimes frustrating. The language course I'm doing keeps being "tweaked" for some reason and that puts you in a different place than you were before, meaning sometimes you end up learning stuff you learned a while back, or sometimes you end up ahead and missing necessary steps. That aside it's definitely helping me learn a language, and duo's daily reminders are great, I'd definitely forget otherwise!

Awful. I've updated the app to the latest version hoping the constant bug of audio missing in the English - Swedish course have finally been dealt with, but no. I keep reporting the problem with the audio for about two weeks now and all I get is "Thanks! your feedback has been recorded". I cannot complete some exercises because of this annoying problem.

I used to love this app, but in recent months it has become riddled with errors, there is no feedback, the discussion boards are gone so there is no one to explain the grammar of a certain phrase. I report several mistakes in exercises every week, but they are never corrected. I have been to France several times and took years of French all through college and grad school. I have a six year streak and I use Duo to keep my language skills from getting rusty. Trust me: this app has major problems.

very helpful. nice app. but I've noticed that in korean lessons, we're taught in a wrong way to write some letters. I realized because I'm following a youtube course simultaneously. And sometimes the app freezes and I'm unable to open it, and I lose my streak. I hope you would correct them. Otherwise this is one of the best apps I've ever had.

I like the convenience of this app and that I can do short lessons anytime. I have seen a lot of progress in how much I've learned in spanish and am amazed at how I can communicate in spanish speaking countries. You take out of it what you put into it. I don't enjoy the constant change of how you progress through the app and the levels. In the past few years they have changed the format of the app multiple times. I also don't like that now you only can get 5 wrong where before was unlimited.

Although this app is the best on the free market, grammar explanations are only available on the website and not in-app. This creates confusion when trying to learn a new language and is unreliable long term. If they were to teach the why and how of grammar in the languages, it would be much better as a language learning app. Overall, the ads are not interupptive, and the lessons are alright. Have and would recommend to friends and family.

overall, I enjoy it. i wish there was more one on one conversation to test skills. like chat bots. I would like to see different courses dependent on native language. Going from english to chinese is a whole new language system including pinyin, hanzi, and overall just a new way of reading. I find myself having to pace a lot, and I feel like I can not progress because I do not know the concepts enough to move on even after it says I have "mastered" it. Does not help my whole course changed.

I miss the flashcards partner app. I appreciate the vocabulary section, but I wish you could study them in flashcards form again, not just in mini quizzes. I would also appreciate a greater sentence variety. I've seen some of the sentences so many times I don't have to translate I just know the word order, which isn't so helpful. This is a good app for learning different alphabets and characters though, as well as practicing sentence structure (that you might have studied in a textbook before)

Lately the app lags between sections using up your minutes. I have to re-open it so often to continue. Also the sound stops every once in a while which is frustrating. My husband has the same issues. Not sure if they did any updates as these weren't issues before. Edit: The free option is VERY limited, it's overly repetitive and the practice part doesn't review past difficulties just repeats the same phrases and now you get less points to practice. Not impressed.

It was good for starting out, but it grew less useful with updates. At least for Japanese, all the nouns are always paired with the same adjective(s) ie. Black pants, red car, ble house, 2 birds, 3 cats. It made for a lack of variety, which hindered learning. Also, since the last update, Duo stopped defining new words for me when they were introduced. Duo is putting more effort into animation than into actual learning. The stories are a smart idea, but lack difficulty.

App works consistently well, it's well-organized, and has lots of methods of keeping you engaged and having fun while learning. I'm about 5 months into learning Spanish so far, and it's basically a review of what I learned in high school, but that alone is great. I still have a very basic understanding, but I'm able to communicate a lot more in everyday scenarios. Really I'm doing this review to humbly ask that they change the logo back to normal. Depressed Duo is bumming me out.

I have been using the app for over two years but will be canceling my subscription before it renews again. The app was good until a few months ago. Frequently, when I am granted a powerup, the XP isn't doubled as it should. Sometimes, it only doubles every other exercise. I reported this, but there is obviously no customer service. I really liked the forum because it helped me understand my mistakes. It would be nice if you could pull up the guidebook during an exercise.

This used to be a 5 star review. But now they randomly moved all the chinese lessons around. Making my progress basically useless because I can't review previous lessons, SINCE THEY DON'T EXIST ANYMORE. This change makes it so I have to start over. But because the lessons still show that I have "completed" them, even though they changed. There's no sense of actual improvement. And I can't even keep track of where I was. I am so beyond disappointed and frustrated.

I've been using Duolingo for several years. It's an amazing app and it's improving constantly. Great job! However, I miss the 'comments' feature in every exercise - the discussion there was really helpful sometimes. It helped me understand some things that were not explained in duo's tips. I would really appreciate it if you bring it back :(

I feel used car salesman vibes about missing streaks, so I'm trying to turn most of the notifications off. I recommended this for anyone who has similar feelings. I know that research suggests that repeated daily learning intervals is the best way to learn, but I don't learn because of research, I learn because your in-app content, art, and variety is truly excellent. Please stop changing Duo's face. His uber-defeated/depressed look feels manipulative, not inviting. Happy Duo = more $$$ IMO ü§ë.

This is a great app!! I am a beginner learner and am enjoying this app. The interactions are great, it's not time sensitive and it helps you to set goals. It also provides you the opportunity of going back and correcting the exercise you got wrong which I love!! I love the interactions and there are motivators along the way. The daily goals are awesome. It also gives you a chance to revise what you learned the day before, before going into new lessons. Thumbs up to the creator of this idea

For a free app, this is fantastic. Love the gamified experience and the fact that Duolingo offers such a variety of languages. Honestly, I'm hooked. Combined with a variety of other materials to work on other skills, I think it's a effective tool for language-learning due to its addictive nature. I'm a high school foreign language teacher and recommend it to my students as well for extra vocabulary practice. :)

Can't fault it, with a very useable and generous free route, and an obviously enhanced paid route at a very reasonable price, it is properly impressive. I can't speak to advanced levels, but beginner and rusty returner experience is excellent. You can plainly see the quality linguistic and pedagogical maturity, together with great application in software/web user interface. My only concern is that it seems to be sharing data with Google and Unity; possibly innocuously but I don't know.

I love the app, the only downfall is there are a lot of ads, and I mean A LOT of ads, like, I can't go one unit without an ad popping up outta no where, but, still a great way to learn a new language. Plus, a lot of people think that Duolingo is just Spanish, but you can do French, Italian, Japanese, heck, I'm learning Spanish and Irish, so, you can learn so many different languages on this app. 9.5/10 recommended.

While I understand why they want to push users to upgrade to Super status, and have put up with the 30sec ad that runs after most lessons, the new changes to this screen are pathetic. They removed the "no thanks" option and the only way to bypass the screen is clicking the small, unresponsive X in the top corner... Usually 5-6 times before it closes. The only button presented to users is to continue with a costly recurring billing option.

this app is SOO good. I'm learning/practicing Russian, and so far I know simple sentences. there's a lot of stages with different topics that you would use, such as, greeting, foods, and drinks,jobs, etc. for example- (Is mark a coach?) it's been going really well and I'm honestly starting to understand Russian. there's so many languages to choose from, different levels, and even has a leader board. üíØ definitely recommend it if you're looking to learn a new language! best part? It's free!!

Even with premium, there are still prompts to buy gems, and unreasonably high prices for freezes and timer boosts, the latter specifically. The rapid review is ridiculously difficult, taking roughly 10 tries to finish a single star. Frequent UI changes. Chinese only goes to a1 level and is a little obtuse. Power up chests are inverted(morning one opening at night and vice versa), don't Open for the whole time period, or at all. Got rid of the conversations feature. Doesn't fix chronic bugs.

It's OK. But there are better apps out there. This app can become annoying, and demotivating after a while. I was using it to brush up on a language I hadn't spoke for 15 years, I found the sentences they gave to be unnatural. Expected responses are too ridged. Often there are 2 or 3 right ways to respond, you have to guess what they are expecting. Sometimes their English is simply wrong or too americanised The gamification is pointless, eventually demotivating. You can do better.

This app is useful for basic vocabulary & pronunciation. I've used it mostly for French, but also Danish, & Spanish. I don't feel like I am making much progress or am learning the reasons why the language is what it is, which is frustrating. I've been using it for 1.5 years. There used to be a section with long reading and listening, when I first started. Now it's short lessons only. I miss the longer format lessons. I miss using a book and understanding basic rules and tenses.

first let me say that I think everyone's learning style is different. I personally have learned a lot from duo and really enjoy using the app. they do use friendly competition as a form of motivation but I've learned that it is not required for you to engage in competition for you to use the app. you can totally just focus on the lesson aspect and ignore those parts. I also really enjoy the animation and characters in the app, it makes it fun!

The gamification of learning makes it easier to stick to, but it's very foundational. For the paid version I would have hoped for some more comprehensive learning material. It also teases you with fun little learning tidbits on loading screens but it loads too fast to be able to read them üòÇ You'll know the language on paper but need to find additional resources for learning to converse fluently.

Depending on which language you're practicing, sometimes the annunciation of some words are difficult to discern. I'm learning Korean and French. In Korean, the AI voice makes it difficult to know the difference between vowles and consonants and you get it "wrong" because it's not clear. In French, when you speak into the mic, you can say the phrase and it won't pick up on certain annunciations and you get it "wrong". Super frustrating and is the main reason I will not pay for a subscription.

Basically app version of my 90s high school Spanish textbook. Nothing groundbreaking. The voices are absurd and don't sound like ANY Spanish speaking person I've ever met. Visuals in the app are also problematic. Points don't always accurately accrue, and common Spanish phrases from different parts of the world keep getting dinged as incorrect. Even if you report it, the app does not correct your total. Nor is there any acknowledgement from Duolingo about the errors reported. Fine for free.

Simply the best language learning app available. I've tried many other options both paid and free but Duolingo beats them out easily. They are great about continuing to improve as well when complaints are voiced. A few examples. There are now chapter summaries before each unit giving context outside memorization. They've got reading lessons outside of the standard quizzes encouraging real understanding of what is read. I could go on but I'm out of space!

Really dislike the negative notifications. Now the app icon has changed to a grumpy face. This is really unhelpful for someone that has grown up in a negative environment. Positive encouragement is much more appreciated. Also, I have hearing loss. I wish I could turn off the speaking part in settings. There's no way for me to hear the words properly so that I can repeat them perfectly.

Love learning German and Greek through this! The only thing stopping it from getting 5 stars is the lack of explanation in actual lessons. I wish a little thing could pop up from the side that could clarify certain rules with, for example: Das, der and die. I know it has it but I wish it was more integrated into lessons. Overall solid app for any language learners! Edit: still loving this app, however the ending fire animation when you see your streak is going is terrible now.

I like the app very much and I have bought the plus subscription. But the issue which I am facing and it's very consistent is when the double XP time starts the aps loading times increases. Its really annoying because the double time is running and the quest is still loading. This happens most of the time when it's double XP activated. Developer team please look into it's very annoying and discouraging. Due to this I am giving 3 star. If improved then I will re rate the application.

I started off having a free trial for duolingo that was supposed to notify me before I'd be charged, it didn't so I ended up paying over $100 for a year of super duolingo. I was unable to get a refund so I'm trying to make the most of the app but it frustrates me when the apps microphone just doesn't pick up anything I'm saying. I checked that it's not my phones microphone and I have excellent WiFi strength, I lose points because the app doesn't hear me.

Great app, its making it super easy to learn Spanish. However, the app fails on my phone constantly, when I go to choose words for the answers, it won't choose any of the words. Have updated the app many times, and it always glitches again. Also, it doesn't do the speaking feature at all. Would give 5 stars if not for these factors

You app is marvelous, I even have a super duolingo subscription, BUT you have a really annoying design flaw on android, the "can't listen now" or "can't speak now" button is placed rather inconvenient, you must be getting this a lot. I keep hitting it by mistake which is rather annoying and really impractical during exercises with time limit. I would suggest to move the button somwhere to the upper part of the screen, also maybe add an option to turn ON listen/speak inside an exercise.

I've used Duolingo of and on now for over 10 years the lessons are fun and interactive , and I can honestly say they have gotten better over time . Update I've had the app for a while.and I've noticed some glitches , little annoyances like telling me a sentence is wrong when I have the exact sentence / word / spelling so I'll be penalized and then move on but its annoying , and there are Soo many adds in the free version . Thinking I might need to shop around

This app has been improved a lot in the past 10 years. The animation and interface now is appealing. I just wanna recommend that in the word arrangement exercises, they should allowed users to move words around within the sentences instead of cancel and move them down and rearrange every words when users make one mistake. It would save so much time.

Owner doesn't support product. This app was designed before dark mode became prevalent but they still use dark colors regardless of what visual mode you are using making much of the tutorials unreadable. The dark red color is the worst but the dark green isn't much better. Most pages go by so fast that it is impossible to review the information on the page so even if you get the answer right, you don't know what it is.

At 1st the app was great, I was enjoying learning a new language, then the free version became more competitive. you got 5 lives, after 5 mistakes you couldn't do anything until the next day, unless you won extra lives. I still want to learn so I now use the app as a paid subscriber to get the unlimited lives. There's always goals to reach, challenges to beat, different leagues to get promoted to, or demoted from if you choose to be competitive, I don't as that takes the fun out of it for me.

Duolingo is good. But the only thing it needs to improve on REALLY, REALLY badly is adding *grammar notes* throughout the lessons so that we can read to understand the change in feminine and masculine nouns and accents. Because then it would prevent people from searching for days on which term to use (because let's be honest, some of these aren't easy to find), so, then, spend more time in Duolingo understanding it.

A solid app for an intro to language and becoming familiar with grammar and characters. The competitive aspects can inhibit my language retention and make effort feel hollow, but overall I find it worth it. I do have the Super Duolingo, and recommend it if your focus or momentum is interrupted by ads. Whilst not terribly intrusive, knowing that an ad waits for me at the end of a lesson made me slightly avoidant toward working on lessons.

Excellent app! Well put together and easy to use Other than small issues, I've got no problems with the app, (e.g. monthly challenges, sometimes it miscalculates how many I've completed, + it does use American English, which could be confusing, but it doesn't impact the learning too much) I use it to compliment school lessons, and it broadens vocabulary, strengthens grammar, etc. I don't know whether you could become fluent solely through the use of Duolingo, but I definitely recommend this app!

This is by far the worst language app around. Accents on recordings are miss matched, and it is NOT "ADA COMPLIANT". There are no Instructions on how to use this app. Even the free version is not worth your time, I've wasted 94 days of my life. If you believe your answer should be accepted, no one looks at it, or gets back to you as to why. I'm going up against people who have up to 3 yrs experience in the language I'm trying to learn. Do better duolingo!

Absolutely superb app - especially if you pay for it (I hate ads, and a quick blast of the free tier early on convinced me to pay immediately...). At times it can be unreliable when you do the speech challenges, but other than that my only gripe is that it BADLY needs an English choice that is not American - the rest of us English speakers around the world frequently need to translate answers twice ;) (Can see a lot of the other reviews say the same thing, hehe)

It's really only good for a first taste of a new language, maybe for about a year, to get a few phrases and words down. Many languages don't have any grammar explanations AT ALL. In the practice tab the word review always reviews the same words, has been a bug for months. I can do that better myself just using a flashcard app and a grammar book. Though the streak is very motivating for me personally, the leagues not so much.

Have been an avid user for about two years. Spanish 19+ months and Hindi 8+ months. I wish Bengali were an option too, there's a lot of languages in India, untapped potential growth for the app. I recommend Duolingo to many. Fun, interactive, the repetition and silly stories are great. Being able to team up with your friends for goals too. After the first year I signed up for the Super Family plan, really great for kids or others who would otherwise get discouraged easily. Great app.

I think there is a bug in this app that doesn't allow me to move forward to the next lesson unless I closed the app and start it again. I checked that I updated to the latest version. But it is very annoying that this happens now and it happened once in the past. This time it doesn't seem to go away. Also, another problem I have is double XP doesn't work. Every time I complete the third task or complete the circle of lessons, it tells me that I get double XP, but I actually often don't get them

As a native italian speaker I have noticed that there are a lot of mistakes. The last few months there have been a lot of grammar mistakes as well. Were last year Duolingo with comment on your suggestion, now they don't and leave the mistakes in it. Sentences don't make sense, the app has gotten terribly bad in the last few months. I cannot speak for other languages but if they are like Italian then you are not learning the language properly. I am a paying customer for years but will not renew.

Duolingo is a hit or Miss App. I used it for school, but it was a meh. This time, I use it for a language I'm learning for fun, and it already has me learning a lot of words in just a week. Duolingo has all sorts of language choices and has even updated since I last used it. It has writing/typing, speaking (new since I last used it), forming sentences, and other sorts of forms of learning. Although, duolingo is definitely not for everyone. Some like, and others don't think it works for them.

Pros: 1. it is free (though the 5 hearts are quite limiting), 2. the gamification is fun. Cons: The setup and the lesson order does not make any sense. Here I am in the section 3, unit 2 of Russian course titled "get around town, describe cities" and more than half of the questions was about fitting clothes, and birds which are many or few depending on the season... in the meantime there are at least 3 different words for "near" and you get zero help as to when and why use one or the other.

A great way to learn a new language with fun incentives to keep you going when you don't always feel like it. I like the way it reviews past lessons to keep your memory fresh. I find I still need to practice talking to someone to practice the language. I'm very happy with this app and program and highly recommend it. Much better than repeating words and sentences from CDs which never worked for me.

Genuinely helpful for my learning. It's been a lot of fun learning Chinese through this app! It's not as fun if you already are a decent level at a language though. For me, Japanese has been frustrating because the app expects its particular translations, rather than ones that might omit the subject as you would in natural Japanese. Still, Chinese is fun on Duolingo just learning from scratch!!

It's pretty great - as long as you're only interested in their "top 8" languages. The others are basically left in the scrap heap, with no new developments (generally fine) but more importantly no on going quality control, with some sentences being unnatural (for general sentences, not "my horse walks on strawberries"), and others being completely wrong. I still hold out hope that the "lesser" languages will eventually get the spiffed-up treatment that the Top 8 get.

Interface works. I can see it being a good educational tool....but holy ads batman. The amount/length of ads in the free version make me not want to pay for it. The number of passive aggressive reminders to use it is also annoying. I get a nudge/reminder but the language used is borderline aggressive to get you to open an app that keeps yelling at you to pay for the full version. No thanks.

Audio is far too often indiscernible between similar sounds („Öó vs „Öú), and far too much of the written language is left unexplained before you're expected to know everything about it at unit 2. Too much focus on romanizing. Learning full words is left to brute force memorizing through multiple choice questions. The app has hung on startup twice. The freemium model (even with super) promotes practices that defeat the app's purpose as a learning tool.

This rating is specifically for the Irish course. It is horribly designed, requiring strict memorization of words with sometimes only a small difference. The memorization is needed because the hints are nonexistent for anything requiring even the slightest context, especially pronouns. The audios are also wildly inconsistent in both pronunciation and quality, sometimes being completely inaudible or unintelligible. I am leaving the course purely because it is nearly unusable as it is.

It used to be great, but now its just horrible. Full of unnecessary prompts and notifications, useless interruptions about things other than learning a language, ads after you finish a lesson, bloated with useless features, I wish it was like what the browswer version used to be 10 years ago. No explanations, forums, tables, and nobody to ask questions about a lesson in the community anymore. You just click on the words in order 90% of the time. Also I lost all the badges from 10 years ago

Duolingo is flawless, I've been on it for 20 days now and no glitches, bugs or problems, I love the reminders and it's really neat to learn Spanish. I plan on sticking with this app for a long time. Superlingo subscription is totally worth it. Highly recommend, especially if you want to replace doom scrolling with something productive. 5 stars across the board!!

It's not the be-all-end-all of language learning but it does a great job and is very intuitive! I would give 5 stars but for some reason creating an avatar permanently deletes your old photo-based profile picture. I had to find an old APK on the internet to install on my phone so that the functionality is restored to upload a photo profile picture. I don't like the whole forcing people to use avatars decision... Glad I was at least able to solve it. I was like "oh no what have I done" üòÆ‚Äçüí®

I like the lessons and all the variety I really HATE the competition part and the streak part. when I signed up I thought I said no to the desire to be in "competition" i just want to use this fun app to learn new languages. I hate that after every lesson there is a "choose a streak" reminder. I just exit the app and that's usually the end my lessons for the day. I just want to be able to opt out of the contest leagues and streaks.

Used to be a great app. Now there are WAY too many ads to be productive. And frankly it's not a robust enough language learning program to be worth the monthly subscription fee to get rid of the ads. There are literally ads every 1-2 minutes-- every single time you complete the extremely short modules. That's too much for me, so au revoir Duo!

Good learning app, but you can't cancel your duolingo super subscription easily. When trying to pay for the super monthly, it says an amount for a week, & you think: that's alright, let me subscribe. & it tries to take ¬£60. it says monthly, but you can only pay yearly. you can barely cancel your 2 weeks free, & then it charges you for a year, whether you want it or not. but the base game is alright, but still kind of hard to learn when you can make 5 mistakes, while learining, you make mistakes.

A good method of practicing foreign languages in which you already have SOME knowledge. It might be hard to pick up a new language from scratch with this app, because it doesn't always teach the rules of grammar very efficiently. But if you already know the basics and want to be drilled on a bunch of practice sentences, or improve your pronunciation, this app is super handy and easy to learn.

I like the way it helps people learn. not a lot of apps are used to benefit the world but dulingo is. it's making the world more communicative. one word at a time.üòΩ I also like the way that duolingos reminders are different characters in the game reminding you to keep going. saying things like duo misses you!! and encouraging words when we need them most. it's gentle it's pure. duolingo is amazing and should honestly be appreciated more. beneficial and good app. your efforts are appreciated.

The app is good, but you can not expect anything good since it's free. The main problem I have with learning here is that plural and singular are not explained, so most of the time, I lose a heart. The app has fixed sentences that give no opportunity to use a different word that has the same meaning in a sentence, so you are forced to use words that were programmed into the unit. It gets boring and frustrating after making the same mistakes and reading and listening to the same sentences.

The gamification makes me stick with it so I am learning rapidly. The content is presented in a practical order so I can actually apply the lessons speaking the language. I recommend Premium/family. The product has improved a lot over the years and the new feature allowing one to test out to get to the right level allowed me to give Dou another try and now I am hooked!

The best free language learning app is one that offers a wide range of interactive and engaging lessons, practice exercises, and resources to help users improve their language skills. It should also have a user-friendly interface, personalized learning tools, and the ability to track progress and set goals. Additionally, the app should provide opportunities for real-world practice, such as conversation practice with native speakers or language exchange programs. Overall, the best language learn

This is an easy start to learning, however it is done through repetition as opposed to teaching. This could be much better with some more effort. Some of the tools are extremely primitive, for example you have to erase the entire sentence if you fat fingered an incorrect word. A better approach would be to allow reordering words. The complex sentences and phrases are often not explained or translated - it doesn't allow you to learn or understand the meaning behind the presumably slang phrases.

I only recently started using Duolingo, but it is brilliant so far. I have learned so many Japanese words in a short amount of time. Duolingo is also very good at encouraging you to keep learning with fun lessons and a day streak system. am currently on 12 streak (12 days in a row). This helps motivate you, which is good if you struggle to stay motivated. I would highly recommend.

At first, I felt embarrassed to try Duolingo. I want to be a translator and an interpreter, but as a person in college trying to finish my Associate's Degree, I've had some setbacks trying to reach this goal. But, when I got and tried out Duolingo, I felt more invested in it over time. I love how it encourages me to make mistakes and learn from the lessons about language. I also loved how it's set up like a game to improve at. Lastly, I love how many different features it has. It's great!

It would be nice if you could test out of the kanji you already know. Having to review over and over and over until you get questions on the next set is so discouraging that I've been skipping the kanji practice entirely because of it. It's unusable. I wish the screen would rotate when I turn my tablet upside down so the charging port wasn't facing me and I wish that I could set the font size larger without parts of text or kanji getting cut off. I need bigger fonts to see.

The actual learning is fine (I use the free version) but there are so many annoying and seemingly unnecessary and separate point systems for collecting diamonds, or hearts or streaks, or up grading your word collector. I still have no idea why these are important. And it pesters me and attempts to guilt me for not using the app everyday. Its a good thing overshadowed with a lot of unnecessary, confusing and unhelpful kitsch.

I was enjoying the app and decided to accept the free trial offer. Play store shows that I am on the free trial as time ticks away..... yet I am getting no additional benefits of this "super" level of membership. Seems like it's either a waste or a glitch and I guess I'll be canceling because the ap offers zero support for issues. I haven't been able to find any way to get help other than warning the rest of you by leaving a review. üôÑü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

All tips, discussions, and guidance has been removed. Words aren't introduced anymore, they show up mostly in review units and I'm often expected to know how to spell a word I've never seen or heard before without hints. My streak has been broken more than once when I had done a lesson and/or had available freezes. Some languages have no audio or vowels so I've no idea how I'm supposed to learn anything. Endangered languages are abandoned and there's no resources to be found online or in app. üò´

After using DuoLingo premium for coming up to 3 years now, the app is a great starting place, covering the basics and sentence structure. Beyond this, it feels lacking and I wouldn't confidently have a conversation in a new language. The app was better in the old learning style, focusing on topics and allowing you to revisit them easily. You knew what you were getting into and where you were at. The new style of learning feels messy and the value has declined a lot. Goodbye 761 day streak :(

Good app for basic learning and practice. It could be better with more details on verb tenses and conjugations guidance as well as pronouns. I would appreciate a quick reference popup when you get an exercise wrong that will take you to the appropriate description/lesson to explain why you got it wrong. Overall, a very helpful app.

It's a money grab. The app isn't designed to focus on your specific language development. It gamifies your experience so you're distracted with leagues and points. You can't focus on your own development and non-competition use of the app isn't allowed. The AI-designed lessons don't focus on new material once you've learned something. App is designed to slow your learning experience so it takes you longer to learn the language, wasting your time and prioritizing profit first.

It's a very good app for learning new languages. The only issue I'm having is that after the first exercise the app lags and doesn't record touches and it results in bad responses or the timer passes when I get to the last question. It's not a big deal but it's annoying. Plus loosing crystals for this issue is not that cool. üòï That's why the 4 and not 5 stars. But still, great job devs! LE: The 40xp challenges should really take into account if there are long translations. 1.30 is not enough.

10/10 app that makes learning a new language fun and engaging. The lessons are easily digestible, flow nicely, and do a great job of reinforcing and building on each other. They offer a generous two week free trial for Super, which allows you to test and see if it's right for you. They also send you a courtesy notification that your free trial is about to expire, reminding you to cancel if you don't want to continue. The family plan is nice for the whole family to learn a language together.

The new update makes the app load slow in between lessons and glitches often when trying to load that I earned the dual 2x exp. The new update now prevents from seeing how many units for future sections. I liked knowing what was coming up as it was much easier to manage my progress and accept how much further I still had to go. Once I make it to daily recap, super will be a thing of the past for me.

This is an incredible resource for learning languages. Yes, you will likely need other resources for many languages, but Duolingo is such an effective tool for learning vocabulary and keeping the language you're learning fresh in your mind. It's engaging and offers vocabulary in ways that make it very easy to memorize new words in context. I would recommend this to ALL beginners as an incredible starting point! (Learning Japanese for 3mo @review)

App is VERY aggressive about pushing notifications and reminders and other pressure mechanics such as streaks and icon that becomes ugly when not used in a while. A lot of time is wasted waiting for animations and other nonsense between lessons. Very frustrating. Be a good app and stfu. I'll use you when I get the time. Otherwise good teaching approach by gamification and quick bursts with rewards.

Amazing for building a foundation in a language and building confidence. Mind you it's not to become fluent but it definitely helps push you there. Only problem is they practically only update Spanish and German (and a couple others). I understand there's higher demand, but for people like me learning less high demand languages (ie. Polish in my case) there's no updates ever. We don't have stories, speaking questions, nor grammar help. But other than that, great experience so far. Try it out! :)

This is rigged. I feel like the company makes exercises impossible, hoping I'll pay for more time. Words are included in timed exercises that I've never been taught. I really want to study Korean, but if I did, it's so much harder than the other three languages that I'd be sure to be demoted. This is so frustrating. I also wish explanations were given for exceptions to what otherwise seems to be the rule. And I wish we were taught to say practical, rather than nonsensical things.

The app is great, I myself am not a native English speaker, Duolingo really helped me in learning English. But there's a catch, the thing is is that lately I started noticing how Duolingo after adding math lessons and piano lessons ‚Äî the app became really buggy.. It might be that it's because of the sanctions because I myself live in Russia, and a lot of apps started to have some problems. But I just want to ask the developers ‚Äî your app is great, if its just buggy then please fix it.

First the bad points: I wish it provided the option for English English not American English. I have to translate twice to get to the answer the app wants. There's no way you could learn a language on this app alone. Explanation is inadequate. It never gives the gender of nouns when you first encounter them which is bizarre and unhelpful. you move too quickly from one topic to the next to master them. As an experienced learner I have found some of the phrases new to me and very useful.

This app got poor. They removed comments and a grammar explanation. It looks like it got more oriented on making money. Some courses look like they are not developing at all. And there are lots of errors like not giving you an extra 15 min for a level up lesson. It seems that they are really not caring about the reports. I sent lots of them, and if before, I sometimes was getting notifications on e-mail and mistakes and issues fixed - now the mistakes are staying the same.

Buggy, just lost my xp-boost out of nowhere. Was finishing my level 3 quest and ended up with no reward. And there goes the weekly happy hour. Also DON'T BUY SUPER. ADDS after EVERY lesson. After trying duolingo super it started bombarding me with adds after the subscription went out. It was not like that before I got it, so I can only assum it was caused by my subscription running out. Made a "quick" 10 minutes session turn to 15.

I'm still pretty early on but Duolingo seems to break it down in an easily digestible way that helps you remember each step rather than just moving on right away. there's a bit too many ads on non super which is why I gave it a 4 star, the family plan seems like a pretty good deal but I would have preferred if they had a month to month option rather then a yearly cost as I'm not sure if my family will remain commited once their chosen languages start to get harder and only year option is scummy.

The audio is missing from the lessons. Impossible to learn pronounciation (I just started learning German in Duolingo but encountered this problem, making it much more difficult to study). I have to skip listening tasks because I've no idea what the audio's supposed to be. I don't think I will be using the app until the problem is fixed.

TOO BORING! After I completed all the hindi units, all that is left in the course is 6 daily refresher lessons with the same set of sentences repeated like a broken record. No new vocabulary is introduced, and nothing you learned from the course is revised except the very last bit of it. In my case, I'm forever stuck in a loop of repetitive refreshers of the "past tense" in ALL SIX LESSONS which are clone lessons of the same grammatical rule with the same vocabulary, repeated DAILY! Demotivating

I love its conveniences - being able to turn off sound practices temporarily, and it will correct you when not using accents but doesn't require them for a correct answer (would take extra time typing). Previously didn't love there not being enough game elements but that's been super upped as of 2024. Another addition I love as a points junkie is earning experience by reviewing and mastering past lessons. Only current complaint is Oscar's the worst.

The experience of learning is overall pretty good. Theres a bug where I'm stuck on Unit 9 of Section 3 of Spanish cause it keeps sending me back to the chest of Unit 8, also there should be a retire feature, your streak is frozen and you have to do all of the courses you sought out on doing. You should also be able to delete course data entirely (not reseting), per example, i want to delete my chinese course data, one day i started it for the memes and ended it the next one.

No longer a fan, keeps getting worse. I am asked to type what I hear without seeing a translation of what I typed, a whole bunch of words are appearing in my lessons that I never learned before without showing what the words actually mean (which I then lose hearts for if I don't guess correctly), they took away reviewing mistakes which is helpful when learning, many phrases are ones no normal person uses, there is more memorizing words than learning, and the grumpy, emo characters are annoying.

I've submitted bug errors 3x in the last week (with no response). Have had trouble with the audio on listening exercises, attempts to do a lesson and it kicks me out and then not receiving an xp boost when I had earned it and was given that notification. I'm thinking of switching to another language app or at least not pay to use this one.

I like the gaming aspect of it. Play against other people for top positions. There is even a very rare achievement that I will get this Sunday: finishing #1 in Diamond league. You can definitely learn to speak a language with Duolingo BUT you have to always keep practicing. Not only with Duo, but also on other places (I use VRChat). What I don't like: Exercising is often repetitive. VERY repetitive. They don't have Thai. Free version sucks (one <3/4 hours). I really like Duolingo learning style!

Unless you read very carefully, you won't realize that when the free trial ends, there is only the option of paying for a whole year. The monthly amount is not what you actually pay but you have to pay up front for a whole year. I could afford monthly but an annual charge is beyond my capacity. So, I'll continue with the free version until I can find something less deceptive. I would gladly pay for it but not the upfront price demanded.

I love it! Duolingo honestly helped me learn so much in just a week, plus the lessons are fun too, so it doesn't feel like some boring chore! It's built kinda like a game, and it bought my competitive side out to finish my lessons and earn a good streak and i look forward to the daily lesson everyday.and Its not to long so it doesn't take up more than 10 minutes of your time but it also depends on your speed, it's rlly good ! It's so good, I would highly recommend it. üëå

had low expectations, I assumed I would delete the app within a week of install. Will be trying a month of "Super Doulingo' will update if things change

I faced a minor yet frustrating problem where answers contain extra details beyond the voice prompt. As a beginner, I encountered a Japanese question "bengoshi to sensei," where I had to choose the translation. I picked "lawyer and teacher," but it was marked wrong because I omitted "a." They need to implement their app with more possibilities that users can choose from. Instead of showing as a "wrong answer", showing as "this is a good answer but an even better one is this".

the format works really well, mostly. it would be helpful to be able to make more spelling errors, it would be nice to earn more mistakes while learning, not by ads. nice to start a day with 10 instead of 5 most times I get the grammer backwards but it would be nice if the explanation of the grammar structure were in some of the lessons instead of just not knowing why you do or don't use this form of the word. but really if I make no learning ganes in a day its because Im not perfect!

The streak and push notifications are very effective. Duo helped me jumpstart forming habits. It's not as technical and indepth as traditional language learning but you will definitely learn especially if you just want to spent a few minutes a day for language learning. I do miss the comments section after every question. It was quite disorganized then but the comments were helpful with the intricacies.

Brilliant. Edit: Really enjoy using Super Duolingo but it's too expensive to pay in one lump sum. I think the developers can well afford to make it a monthly subscription instead of yearly - at the same price, not a rounded up price. I spent way more time using the app with the trial - your customers are worth more than advertisers. I'm knocking a star off on this basis.

I'm gonna rate Duolingo a 4 stars because this is really great for people that are wanting to learn a new language especially for the beginners, and it realistically shows how long it will take for you to master it. and actual process. now you don't have to have a stressful time learning a new language in the internet or in books when you have dualingo there to guide and help you

I think, it's the best app teacher that teaches a language in a better way ,it helps me to learn different languages at the same time,it has also a reminder and rewards too,it helps me a lot to correct my pronunciation and it has a great setting for the practice or new words , everyday it teaches me some new words at the same time it also include practicing of the previous phrase

Awesome app! Duolingo is in its own class. I'd have rated 5 stars, but for a recurrent issue I've been experiencing. I wish they would help you with a list of all the vocab you've been introduced to and another for how much of it you mastered. Or maybe like a star system where the more stars that are colored by each word symbolizes how often you get it right or something. It would be so nice for review since I always run through the lessons and forget to write down the new words. Still though, the more often you practice, the better you'll get. Solid app.

It's a great way to keep you on track especially if you're a little competitive and try to move up the leaderboard. Some of the phrases and things they teach however aren't what I would class as normal everyday conversation eg: who takes a bear with them to a party? But hey, that could be about learning different pronunciations for similar looking words.

It's a very great app to learn languages. The recent addition of the widget makes it easier to do a lesson regularly and keep your streak alive! Duolingo Super makes the experience even better with some cosmetic, and the practice hub which helps me practice what matters! All in all, I like using this app a great deal! Screen time well spent!

Super user reporting in. My course doesn't have speaking exercises üëé or matching madness ones üëçüëç. Timed exercises are BS, especially getting 3*. Terrible computer generated pronunciation of Mandarin. Also, the keyboard doesn't seem to be available on mobile as it is on the desktop. The speaking exercises are terrible and mark it correctly even if you completely butcher the pronunciation. Lastly, the app icon is sad and depressing which made me uninstall the app as no one to change that unless you upgrade to paid membership.

üåé Realistically not great for travelling. I studied Duolingo for 3 months every day before going to Japan and was missing plenty of common vocabulary/phrases (ex. ordering at a restaurant, asking if I can use the restroom, asking for the bill, "and" sentences, "or" questions...) We should be able to skip from one circle too another (too repetitive). The fast match game is a very good idea.

1. the sound effect is WAY LOUDER than the words being spoken. with sound effects on, you can not use the app on the bus or train. 2.the practice writing hiragana system is too forgiving. it doesnt train you to remember and accepts any squiggles as input. the constant 'f-u-pay-me' interruptions are bearable, and they give you a couple free premium days where the app is just nice. if the ads would just tell me how much money they want i might consider paying something, but they are just obnox.

it works pretty well, and I'm learning steadily (I think!). I understand the desire to monetise the app, but i do think penalising mistakes contradicts the otherwise effective learning approach. It probably does make some people slow down and pay more attention though. Anyway, give it a go, I reckon!

Starts out fun and exciting, but when you get far enough, it stops accepting the correct answers so frequently that it sometimes becomes nearly unusable. It is also the case that this app is fairly eurocentric as far as the languages that are well-supported. It might have been a better experience if I were to try to learn Spanish or German. I like Duolingo it's not a bad app and appreciate it being free, however I have one BIG complaint I wish they would change. I wanted to get the Duolingo pro and was hoping you could do a month or two. Unfortunately you can't it is a whole year at once or nothing. So a payment of over $80 and not monthly. I can't do that. Pretty good overall, but the speaking responses are difficult because the microphone doesn't register words correctly. I worked on it again the next day and it started flagging personal names as incorrect, which is ridiculous. The app itself is very good, learning Spanish in Duolingo is really fun and interesting. Sometimes this bug appears and sometimes not, that's really weird and disturbing. 3 stars because of this bug.

App is great, the only reason i give it 1 star is because the spoken exercises stopped working. If i try a few times it ends up giving me a mistake and removing a heart. Tried to update the app with no effect. I sent an email about this bug and never got any reply. I can't find another way to get techincal suport.

Great app. It's very easy to do your first steps into a new language with it. The learning units are short and motivating. I wish I could change my profile picture to a custom one but it's not possible on the app and also this feature has been removed from the desktop browser version. This is a very frustrating ongoing problem. When I am supposed to translate by tapping the words in "bubbles", the bubbles will either not work at all, leading me to have to quit and forfeit all of the work that I've done up to that point, because I can't move on from the exercise, or only one or two bubbles will go up, and no other bubbles will move, meaning that I lose points for getting it "wrong", even though the bubbles wouldn't move. PLEASE FIX THIS!!!!! THANK YOU.

It's pretty good if you're learning one of the popular languages (english, spanish, french, etc). The social part and gamification are really good, but this neglect of some of the couses are very demotivating.

The app and the lessons in themselves are great... BUT Since I'm not paying for "super" and I'm on a 100+ days streak.... I MUST watch their annoying AF plug for "super" EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. It's a good app but nothing really sticks. I'm a fast learner and understand most things quickly but nothing here has really stuck, maybe it's just me but.. it's good if you're just tryna learn somethin' quick before a trip but not good for full learning. It's also way too competitive and makes you focus more on moving up a league rather then taking your time and learning. It is a good app but just not for me

Perfect lessons, specific-language leaderboards, adding people, avatars aren't forced to everybody yet (And some people hate them) and these XP challenges are a cheat-trick to win leaderboards should all be fixed. Order: "Perfect lessons" are irritating. Specific-language leaderboards aren't really specific-language, as you can switch courses after you've already registered on the tournament on a course. I have tried learning Spanish with Babble but just couldn't get into it. It was just a chore. Duolingo is totally different! I personally think this app is a really greater way to learn basic and easy words of a language. However, there are two major disappointments of the app that being its not add- free and mean that you are interrupted after every lesson and can be a hindrance the other being a its streak reminder though I do appreciate it can be really annoying to be reminded however its not that troublesome overall the game is a great and fun daily activity you can add to just about anyone's schedule

Love this! although, I want to know if I'm saying things correctly, but it doesn't have a speaker button, if it does, please tell me. The app is pretty buggy, at least on Android. Duolingo is an excellent language-learning app! I've found it incredibly helpful in improving my language skills. So far so good. I don't like the ads but they do not interrupt a lesson, they come after some lessons. The app is generous in giving away their paid version if you play enough. Okay first off, love everything about this app. The accessibility, the art, the memes. BUT one thing I would want changed is how long the units are. The Duolingo learning approach really suits me. I prefer the oral and aural approach rather than focusing on learning written vocab. Duolingo makes learning a language really fun! I had it before when I tried learning French, but eventually uninstalled it because it wouldn't let me log in. Using it to learn Portuguese. It's ok but not nearly as good as it used to be when I was learning Swedish a few years ago. If I could I would rate a 3.5, this app is really great! My opinion of the app has been dropping a lot lately. Removing the sentence discussions has been a huge loss. I made heavy use of those to understand mistakes or sentences I didn't quite get. Duolingo is a fantastic way to learn Spanish, by having you practice all the ways you will be engaging with it...listening, speaking, reading, & writing. he may have kidnapped my family a few times but other than that this is a really helpful app. I'm learning polish so I can communicate to another friend of mine, and this is teaching basic stuff to learn. So far I'm using the free version with ads, but this app is much better than any other language learning method I've tried. I gave it only 4 stars since the actual vocabulary learning progresses very slowly which makes it hard to advance. the app is great at motivating you but the slow pace takes away from that. I really like the app and the getting used to memorizing the words and sentences. The only the reason I gave it a four was simply because I wish I could learn the language faster, and learn more words in a faster time period. Over all great app and is really nice for people who just want to learn it for fun. It gives really fun lessons, and the pronunciation lessons are really good for people who find it difficult to pronounce words. I really do like this app and think others would too.

The app is great. But, the heart system is an absolute BS. There have been multiple instances where I'm close to completing a lesson on one heart and then I make one mistake and Bam! I lost all my progress. I do have a solution in mind for this. Instead of loosing 5 hearts over multiple lessons, have a 3 or 4 hearts system for every lesson. If one looses all of their hearts, they'll have to do the lesson all over again. This way, one can fix their mistakes and proceed forward.

Italian practice got bogged on same small handful of questions for several weeks now after an upgrade. Have contacted Duolongo multiple times without response. Also the program does not teach grammar or how to conjugate words. I am finding myself going to Google to find out how sentences are structured how to modify words for various tenses etc.

This is the most amazing game my child has been loving it. It is so great for teaching. I would highly recommend it. I'm actually learning Spanish. There's a few things I wish duolingo did, like have a chart of conjunctions and the like. OK, listen to me. This IS the best language learning app. I started this for fun (a good reason), and I got hooked. You most likely will as well.
